page.title: 12Clowes Wood.
page.content: This has been an area of woodland since the{Ice Age.}In Norman times it was part of the {Forest of Arden}which was declared a hunting forest by the Normans. Until the late 15th century the woods were used as a source of material for houses,furniture etc: Cattle and pigs grazed there. The king realised the "source" would disappear eventually so he enclosed woods for 7 years to simulate growth.The Earl of Warwick enclosed New Fallings Coppice and it became known as Earls'wood. Clowes wood takes its name from Catherine Clowes of Tanworth.Recently both woods belonged to {Cadbury's {Trust}but they sold Clowes wood to WARNACT and today it is a {Site of {Special Scientific Interest.}In 1908 the Warwickshire Railway line was brought through the woods and most of the trees were cleared.
